introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.content: The 1st Combined Legion (1CL) is an alliance of independent regiments created to enable coordinated operations, shared logistics, and clear leadership while preserving each regiment's distinct identity.

membership.title: Membership & Structure
membership.intro: Membership is by nomination and approval of the appropriate command. The Legion uses a two-tier structure to balance integration and autonomy.

sections.title: Legion Central Group (LCG)
sections.content: Regiments that opt into fuller integration: they participate in centralized HR/recruitment, contribute to shared logistics, and take on broader command responsibilities.

sections.title: Legion Associate Group (LAG)
sections.content: Regiments that maintain greater independence: they coordinate on joint operations and strategic objectives but may decline centralized HR participation and retain lighter command duties.

governance.title: Command Structure
governance.intro: Authority rests with two complementary command bodies that divide strategic oversight and operational coordination.

sections.title: Legion Central Command (LCC)
sections.content: LCC consists of representatives from regiments that adopt deeper integration (Legion Central Group). LCC sets core policy, approves central-group membership, and elects CLO.

sections.title: Legion Associate Command (LAC)
sections.content: LAC includes representatives from both central and associate regiments. LAC focuses on campaign-level and operational planning.

sections.title: Decision Rules
sections.content: Each regiment in a command holds one vote. Structural changes require the unanimous consensus; routine operational and allocation decisions use a simple majority unless otherwise stated.

officers.title: Officers & Responsibilities
items: Chief Commander (CC) — Provides leadership continuity and resolves critical deadlocks; the office rotates between regiments each month.
Chief Logistics Officer (CLO) — Oversees the operational stockpile, coordinates logistics, and ensures equitable distribution during operations.
Chief Facility Officer (CFO) — Manages facilities and their maintenance.

recruitment.title: Recruitment & HR
recruitment.content: A central recruitment process supports consistent onboarding and placement. Recruits enter via central channels and select a regiment during onboarding. HR tasks (promotions, transfers, disciplinary matters) are coordinated centrally to maintain consistency; transfers between regiments preserve recognised ranks and qualifications where feasible.

operations.title: Joint Operations & Logistics
operations.content: Operations are planned and announced in advance. The CLO publishes stockpile targets and distribution plans; participating regiments supply resources per agreement. Logistics are managed to ensure readiness, fairness, and minimal redundancy.

strategy.title: Strategy & Resources
strategy.content: Commands set strategic objectives and prioritise production to support shared goals. Shared facilities or pooled resources may be established when they improve effectiveness and efficiency.

communication.title: Communication
communication.content: Public channels serve coordination; private or secure channels support formal deliberation. Commanders keep regiments informed and ensure representation during planning and briefings.

amendments.title: Amendments
amendments.content: Framework amendments are proposed within the commands and follow the decision rules of the relevant command body. Structural modifications require the voting thresholds set by those bodies.
